General considerations.description: General considerations for gene and protein articles.

requirements.description: Do not hype a study by listing the authors' qualifications.
requirements.reference: do not hype a study by listing the names, credentials, institutions, or other "qualifications" of their authors.

requirements.description: Focus article prose on the gene or protein rather than the study authors.
requirements.reference: Article prose should focus on what a cited study says about the structure, function, clinical significance, etc. of the gene or protein, not what the gene or protein says about a particular study or the research group who conducted that study.

requirements.description: Mention notable contributions in the discovery/history section.
requirements.reference: Particularly notable contributions along with who made the discovery however should be mentioned in the discovery/history section.

Article name.description: Requirements for naming gene and protein articles.

requirements.description: Use the recommended UniProt protein name if it is relatively short.
requirements.reference: If relatively short, the recommended [[UniProt]] protein name should be used as the article name.

requirements.description: Use a widely used protein acronym or the official HUGO gene symbol followed by '(gene)' if necessary to disambiguate when the protein name is verbose.
requirements.reference: If the protein name is verbose, either a widely used protein acronym or the official [[Human Genome Organisation|HUGO]] gene symbol, followed by "(gene)" if necessary to disambiguate.

requirements.description: Include the taxon in the title for viral proteins to avoid ambiguity.
requirements.reference: If the article is about a viral protein, it is recommended to include the taxon in the title, as "nonstructual protein 2" and "viral protease" can mean many things.

Gene nomenclature.description: Guidelines for gene abbreviations and nomenclature.

requirements.description: Use abbreviations according to the HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee and write them in italic font style.
requirements.reference: The abbreviations of genes are according to [https://www.genenames.org/about/guidelines/ HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee] and written in ''italic'' font style (the full names are also written in ''italic'').

requirements.description: Prefer using abbreviations over full gene names.
requirements.reference: It is recommended that abbreviations instead of the full name are used.

requirements.description: Write human gene names in all capitals and orthologs with only the initial letter capitalized.
requirements.reference: Human gene names are written in capitals, for example ''ALDOA'', ''INS'', etc. For orthologs of human genes in other species, only the initial letter is capitalised, for example mouse ''Aldoa'', bovine ''Ins'', etc.

requirements.description: Use recommended usages of gene symbols: 'the ALDOA gene is regulated...', 'the rat gene for Aldoa is regulated...', or ''ALDOA'' is regulated...
requirements.reference: The following usages of gene symbols are recommended: 'the ALDOA gene is regulated...', 'the rat gene for Aldoa is regulated...' or ''ALDOA'' is regulated...

requirements.description: Avoid redundant phrasing such as 'the gene ''ALDOA'' is regulated'.
requirements.reference: while the following is not recommended: 'the gene ''ALDOA'' is regulated' since it is redundant.

Images and diagrams.description: Guidelines for including images and diagrams in articles.

requirements.description: Keep diagrams to a standard format where possible.
requirements.reference: Where possible, diagrams should keep to a standard format.

requirements.description: Suggest expansions to standardized formatting if the diagram guide lacks sufficient guidance.
requirements.reference: If the diagram guide does not give sufficient guidance on the style for the images in an article, consider suggesting expansions to the standardised formatting.

Infoboxes.description: Requirements for including infoboxes in articles.

requirements.description: Include one or more appropriate infoboxes at the top of each article.
requirements.reference: One or more of the following [[WP:INFOBOX|infoboxes]] as appropriate should be included at the top of each article:

requirements.description: Add the corresponding enzyme infobox if there is only one human paralog assigned to a given EC number.
requirements.reference: If there is only one human paralog assigned to a given [[Enzyme Commission number|EC number]]..., then in addition to a protein infobox, it may be appropriate to also add the corresponding enzyme infobox.

requirements.description: Add a protein family infobox if there is only one human paralog assigned to a Pfam family.
requirements.reference: Likewise, if there is only one human paralog that has been assigned to [[Pfam]] family, then including a protein family infobox may also be appropriate.

requirements.description: Place less useful infoboxes in a section at the end if a large number apply to the article.
requirements.reference: There exist some cases where a large number of infoboxes may apply to an article. You may put less useful ones in a section at the end, laid side-by-side with a table.

Lead.description: Guidelines for the lead section of articles.

requirements.description: Define the scope of the article in the first sentence of the lead.
requirements.reference: The first sentence of the lead should define what the scope of the article is. For genes/proteins in which a human [[ortholog]] exists, "'''<recommended [[UniProt]] name>''' is a [[protein]] that in humans is encoded by the ''<approved [[Human Genome Organisation|HUGO]] gene symbol>'' [[gene]]." would be appropriate.

Gene.description: Guidelines for the Gene section of articles.

requirements.description: Do not unnecessarily repeat basic gene information already contained in the infobox unless especially notable.
requirements.reference: Much of this basic information may already contained in the infobox and should not be unnecessarily repeated in this section unless especially notable.

Protein.description: Guidelines for the Protein section of articles.

requirements.description: Do not unnecessarily repeat basic protein information already contained in the infobox unless especially notable.
requirements.reference: Much of this basic information may already contained in the infobox and should not be unnecessarily repeated unless especially notable.

Species, tissue, and subcellular distrib.description: Guidelines for the Species, tissue, and subcellular distribution section.

requirements.description: Optionally describe species expression, tissue expression, and subcellular localization concisely.
requirements.reference: Optional section that concisely describes what species this gene is expressed..., what tissue the protein is expressed, and which subcellular compartments or organelles the protein is found...
requirements.where: Species, tissue, and subcellular distribution section

Function.description: Guidelines for the Function section of articles.

requirements.description: Describe the function of the transcribed protein.
requirements.reference: Describe the function of the transcribed protein.

Interactions.description: Guidelines for the Interactions section of articles.

requirements.description: Optionally list proteins that interact with the subject protein.
requirements.reference: Optional section that lists proteins that the protein that is the subject of the article is known to [[protein-protein interaction|interact]] with.

Clinical significance.description: Guidelines for the Clinical significance section of articles.

requirements.description: List diseases or conditions resulting from gene mutations or protein deficiencies/excesses.
requirements.reference: List diseases or conditions that are a result of a mutation in the gene or a deficiency or excess of the expressed protein.

History/Discovery.description: Guidelines for the History/Discovery section of articles.

requirements.description: Do not mention research groups or institutions in the article text.
requirements.reference: In general, it is not appropriate to mention the research group or institution that conducted a study directly in the text of the article.

requirements.description: List names of those who made key discoveries in the History/Discovery section.
requirements.reference: However it is appropriate to list the names of those who made key discoveries concerning the gene or protein in this section...

requirements.description: Link the article to the appropriate Wikidata item based on the first sentence of the lead.
requirements.reference: The Wikipedia article should be linked to a Wikidata item of the entity first mentioned in the first sentence of the lead section...

requirements.description: Cite sources densely with inline citations and avoid non-specific references.
requirements.reference: MCB articles should be relatively dense with inline citations... It is not acceptable to write substantial amounts of prose and then add your textbook to the ''References'' section as a non-specific or general reference.

requirements.description: Ensure consistent citation formatting within an article.
requirements.reference: There is no standard for formatting citations on Wikipedia, but the format should be consistent within any one article.

requirements.description: Do not add 'Retrieved on' dates for convenience links to online editions of paper journals.
requirements.reference: Do not add a "Retrieved on" date for [[Wikipedia:convenience links|convenience links]] to online editions of paper journals...
requirements.when: When using convenience links to online editions of paper journals

Navigation box.description: Guidelines for including navigation boxes in articles.

requirements.description: Include one or more appropriate navigation boxes to cross-link related proteins.
requirements.reference: Articles about related proteins may be cross linked by including one or more [[WP:NAVBOX|navigation boxes]] as appropriate.
requirements.where: End or relevant section of the article

requirements.description: Add every article to at least one appropriate category.
requirements.reference: Every Wikipedia article should be added to at least one [[WP:CATEGORY|category]].

Lead.description: Guidelines for the lead section of articles.

requirements.description: Define the scope of the article in the first sentence of the lead.
requirements.reference: The first sentence of the lead should define what the scope of the article is. For genes/proteins in which a human [[ortholog]] exists, "'''<recommended [[UniProt]] name>''' is a [[protein]] that in humans is encoded by the ''<approved [[Human Genome Organisation|HUGO]] gene symbol>'' [[gene]]." would be appropriate.

Gene.description: Guidelines for the Gene section of articles.

requirements.description: Do not unnecessarily repeat basic gene information already contained in the infobox unless especially notable.
requirements.reference: Much of this basic information may already contained in the infobox and should not be unnecessarily repeated in this section unless especially notable.
